The Convergence

By Aidan Walsh

            In the car, illuminated by dusty overhead lights, Edward watched the snow drift by and stick to the passenger side window, freezing and fogging up the glass.  He pressed his face to the glass and looked up; the stars above were rendered invisible, covered by snow-filled clouds.  On all sides, darkness completely enveloped everything, except for a thin beam of light that was being cut open by the headlights of the car as it sped along.  The beam highlighted a slush filled road covered in natural debris from the surrounding woods.  Edward could see fringes of impossibly tall pine trees every time the road banked.  The specks of snowflakes that fell from the heavens above briefly flashed white before hitting the windshield and melting into nothingness.  Edward let out a sigh from the backseat, and looked forward to see Jack staring  at him through the central mirror.  As soon as their eyes met, Jack quickly snapped his focus back to the road.

            “Do you guys want some music?” Jack said, breaking the silence.  “Hudson, you can use the aux cord.”

            Hudson, sitting in the passenger seat next to Jack in the front, nodded.  “Whatever.”

“Microwave, you have any recommendations?” Jack said, looking through the central mirror.

            The guy sitting next to Edward in the backseat looked up from his phone.  “Sure, play some Metallica.  Enter Sandman.”

            “Christ, not again!” Hudson yelled, turning around in his seat.  “That’s all you ever want to play!  That or some other generic rock group.”

            “Generic?  Generic my ass!” the guy yelled.  “It’s Metallica, it’s-“

            “Sorry,” Edward interrupted, gesturing at the guy next to him and looking up at Hudson, “But did you just call that guy ‘Microwave’?”

            All six eyes in the car turned to Edward, shocked.  “Yeah,” the guy named Microwave finally replied.  “It’s a nickname.”

            “Strange nickname,” Edward said. “Where did it come from?”
             Microwave gave Edward an odd sort of look.  “I’m… not sure.”

            “Hm,” Edward said.  He then looked forward to Hudson.  “Can I make a music recommendation?”

            Hudson laughed.  “You serious, man?”

            “What?”

            “Dude, uh – Edward, is it?”

            “Yeah,” Edward replied.

            “You are, like, aware that we’re currently taking you out into the woods to kill you?”

            “Yeah,” Edward replied.  “I was asking about a music recommendation-”

            Microwave laughed.  “A music recommendation!  On your goddamn deathbed!  Alright man.  What do you got?”

            “You guys ever listen to a little band called Timber Timbre?”

~

            “Let’s get something to eat,” Microwave suggested, as the sound of Timber Timbre’s Do I Have Power boomed from the speakers.  Microwave gestured to Edward with his thumb.  “Not a sit down place.  Somewhere where I can watch him in the car while you guys run in and grab some food.”  Microwave pulled a handgun out of his coat pocket for a split second.

            “So I don’t suppose I could convince you to head to a Quiznos?” Edward said, smirking.  Microwave chuckled as he slid the gun back into his coat pocket.

            “Nah, man,” he said.

“What about that Dunkin’ next to the Police Station in town?” Edward asked.

 “Naw, sorry.”

“There’s a Seven-Eleven up the road a little ways,” Jack said.  “We can get stuff there.”  Jack looked through the mirror at Edward.  “Provided that you won’t try anything, that is.”

Edward shrugged.  “You don’t have to worry about me.  I don’t want to get anyone hurt.”

~

            Edward could see that the Seven-Eleven’s parking lot was completely empty as Jack pulled into a spot.  The glass windows of the convenience store illuminated the parking lot with sharp light.  Surrounded by the darkness and frozen cold of the forest of pine trees, the bright green logo and lights made for quite a striking contrast.  Timber Timbre’s Magic Arrow played over the speakers as the car came to a stop in the parking space.

            “What do you guys want?” Jack asked, putting the car into park.  Hudson immediately opened his door and started walking towards the light of the Seven-Eleven, leaving Jack behind.

            “Bag of chips,” Microwave said.

            “What kind, dumbass?” Jack said.

            “Christ, I don’t know.  Doritos, I guess.”

            “What kind of Doritos, dumbass?”

            “I don’t fucking care.  Cool Ranch.”

            “I’ll have Veggie Straws,” Edward said.  “I’ve been trying to watch my figure.”  

Microwave laughed.  “Trying to watch your figure!” he echoed.  But Jack just stared at Edward.

            “Is that really what you want?” Jack asked.  “This is it for food, you know.”

            Edward shrugged.  “Yeah.  I like them.”

            Jack raised an eyebrow.  “Whatever you say.”  He shut the door and walked away as he flipped open his wallet and looked through his funds.

            Then there were perhaps fifteen seconds of Microwave and Edward sitting in the car silently before Microwave turned to Edward, who had been picking at the fabric of the seat in front of him.

            “So how do you really feel about all of this, Edward?” Microwave asked, taking a pack of cigarettes out of his pocket.  “Jokes aside.”

            Edward looked up.  “How do I feel about what?”

            “I mean, you’re going to die.  Like, tonight, I mean.  We’re taking you out to the woods to shoot you.  You understand that, right?

            “Yeah, I got it,” Edward replied.

“Well, are you dealing with that okay?”

            “Do you care?” he replied.  Seeing Microwave’s annoyed facial expression, Edward clarified; “I’m asking honestly, not as some snide remark.”

            “Oh.  Well, I mean, I don’t personally care.  I’m just making conversation,” Microwave said, lighting his cigarette.  He held the pack to Edward.  “Cigarette?”

            “No, I don’t smoke.”  Edward resumed staring forward, and started picking at his fingernails for a  moment.  “I think I’ve kind of accepted it,” he finally said.  “Dying, I mean.  I mean, what’s the use in stressing out about it?  There’s nothing I can do to stop it, so why not just relax, and try to enjoy my last few hours?”

            Microwave laughed a little, and lowered his cigarette.  “Man, that is a wild goddamn answer!”

            “Is it?”

            “Um, yeah.  I mean, most guys just absolutely freak out, yaknow?  They’re always beggin, like, ‘please, don’t kill me!’  And then they try and run, or argue…”

            “Do you ever listen to them?” Edward asked.

            “What?  No.  I got a job to do here, man.”

            “So then it’s pointless to beg.”

            “I mean, yeah.”

            “So there you go,” Edward said.  “I’ll just enjoy my last meal from Seven Eleven-“

            “Oh man, that is depressing,” Microwave said, laughing.

            “What is?”
             “That your last meal is from Seven Eleven.”
            Edward shrugged.  Magic Arrow finished.  Microwave picked up the phone, and opened Spotify.  “What should I play now?” he asked.

            “You mind playing a sad song?” Edward asked.  “I think it would be fitting to go out to one.”

            “Sure, man.  I mean, we’re still like fifteen minutes from the spot…”

            “Oh.  Well, add Whisper in Her Ear to the queue.  Play it when we’re closer.  If you don’t mind.”

            “You got it.” Microwave said.  “Lemme see here… By the Milk Carton Kids?”

            “Yeah.”

            “Added.”  He looked up.  “What do you want me to play right now?”

            “How about Trouble Comes Knocking?”

            “By…Timber Timbre.  Again.  Alright.”  Microwave pressed play on the song.

            Just then, just as the guitar started, light washed over them.  Another car was pulling into the parking lot.  Its figure was abstracted by the blinding headlights.  The grainy sound of the tires crunching the snowy gravel echoed around them.  Microwave looked at Edward.  

            “Don’t try to signal for help.  I’ll have to shoot you right here, right now, plus whoever is in that car.  And I’ll probably have to kill the cashier inside too, since he’s seen Jack and Hudson.  You don’t want to get innocent people killed, do you?”

            “No.  Understood,” Edward replied.

            The car turned around into a spot across the lot – and as its headlights spun away, Edward and Microwave could see the details of the car in full – it was a police cruiser.

            “Shit, shit, shit,” Microwave said, before looking at Edward.  “What I said still stands.  Don’t say shit.  Sit forward.”  Microwave pulled a pistol out of his pocket and held it at an awkward angle, making sure to keep it below the window.  He kept it pointed sideways at Edward’s stomach.

            “Don’t move at all.  Don’t even look at him,” Microwave said.

            Edward nodded and sat forward, but watched through the mirror as an officer stepped out the parked vehicle, and walked through the snow into the Seven Eleven.  Edward could see him through the glass in front of the store, picking through some beef jerky.

            “Don’t get any ideas,” Microwave said.

            “I don’t have any,” Edward said.  “Nothing worth trying, anyway.”

            Edward slowly turned his head to look into the store.  He watched Jack, from within the store, spot the police officer, and nearly drop the bag of chips in his arms.  Jack turned around and gave Hudson what Edward thought to be an urgent look.  Jack quickly speedwalked to the cashier, two bags of chips and a packet of ho hos in his hands.  Hudson followed suit, holding a bottle of Mountain Dew and a slushie.  The officer got in line behind them.  Edward then looked over at the empty police car, before turning back to Microwave.  The pistol was pressing against his stomach.  

“I do have an idea,” Edward said cautiously.  “I’m considering the prospect of just getting out, and running towards that policeman-”

            “What?  No,” Microwave said, pressing the pistol harder against Edward’s stomach.  “I’ll shoot you-“

            Edward shook his head as he winced from the pressure of the gun.  “Exactly.  I think that you’ll just shoot me right here, and then you’ll have to kill that poor officer.  And maybe that cashier too.”

            “Yeah, yeah.  Right,” Microwave said, relaxing the pistol slightly.

            “I’m thinking that the tiny chance of me surviving isn’t worth all that collateral.”

            “Exactly.”

            The front door the Seven Eleven swung open, and Edward turned his head to see Jack speed walking back to the car.  Hudson tailed him.  Edward looked inside the Seven Eleven again; the officer was chatting with the cashier.

            “Christ.  You see that?” Jack said, opening the front door and sliding back into his seat.  “Damned police over there.”

            “Let’s go,” Hudson said, shutting his door and unscrewing the top of his drink.

            Jack looked back at Edward as he turned around to back out of the spot.   “Sorry, chief,” he said, shifting the car into reverse.  “They were out of Veggie Straws.  I got you some Cheetos instead.”  He threw an orange bag to Edward.  “Hope you don’t mind.”

            “Thanks,” Edward said.  The car sped off, and Edward watched the Seven Eleven grow more distant through the rear window.

~

            “Would you say that you have a difficult job?” Edward asked through a mouthful of Cheetos, just as the Milk Carton Kid’s Whisper in Her Ear began to play.  Snow was still bouncing off the front windshield as Jack turned off the main road, driving off into a dirt path.

            Microwave shrugged as the car bounced on the snowy dirt.  “No, not really.  It’s like with any job.  You get used to it after a while.  And this isn’t the only part of it.  We’re kind of general purpose guys.  Sometimes we get assigned this execution stuff, but it’s not always that.”

            “Right.”  Edward looked around at the dark forest that flew past him through the window.  There were a few seconds of silence.

            “What do you do?” Microwave then asked.  “For a living, I mean.”

            “I’m a dealer”

             “Oh, really?”

            “Yeah.”  Edward looked at Microwave.  “Why the shock?”

            Microwave shook his head.  “Dunno.  Just…wait, did you work under Keith, or are you part of the competition?”

            “Keith.”  Edward looked out the window again.

            “Oh.”  Microwave looked out his window at the snow.  “Cold.”

            “It’s not that bad,” Edward said.  “It’s like twenty degrees out.”

            “No, I meant that Keith would kill one of his own dealers for something so petty.  That’s cold.”

            Edward just shrugged, and looked forward at Jack and Hudson “Are you guys all friends?” he asked loudly.

            “Yeah,” Jack said.

            “What do you guys do for fun?” Edward asked. “Assuming that you don’t find this fun.”
             “Bowl, mostly,” Jack replied.

            “I find this very fun,” Hudson said, turning around to Edward and smiling.

            “Christ Almighty, Hudson,” Jack said.

            “I used to bowl a ton back in my college days.”  Edward rubbed his hands together distractedly.

            “We came in second place last year,” Microwave said.

            “In what?”

            “Oh, just a local competition.”

            “Ah.”

            The car rolled to a stop in the middle of the dirt path.  Trees encircled them, seeming to stretch forever in every direction.  

“Here is good,” Jack said.

            “I don’t suppose now would be a good time to ask for a bathroom break?” Edward joked.  But his voice was beginning to break.

            “Fraid’ not,” Hudson said.

            “You can go if you need to,” Microwave said, tossing his cigarette into the snow as he got out of the car.

            They walked through the snow, Edward leading, Microwave keeping his gun pointed down into the ground.  The only source of illumination was the harsh light from the high beams of the car, and it made their shadows stretch out of view into the darkness.  Pine trees shot upwards into the sky, surrounding them on all sides.  As they grew more distant from the car, the sound of the Milk Carton Kids song got softer and softer, fading into the background and being overshadowed by the crunching of boots and the howling of the snow peppered wind.  Finally, Jack stopped and again said, “Here is good.”

            Edward stopped in front of the group for a moment, his back to them.  The music was barely audible then.  He rooted through his pocket before turning around and tossing his wallet to Microwave.

“Best not to let money go to waste,” he said, shrugging.  “I think there’s a Five Guys gift card in there, too.”

“Thanks,” Microwave replied.  He stood for a moment, Edward’s wallet in hand, considering his options, before opening it and taking the driver’s license out.  He tossed it back to Edward.  

“In case someone finds your body fifty years down the line.  Keep it in your pocket,” Microwave said.

Edward shivered and nodded, shoving the ID in his pocket.  He turned back around, facing away from Microwave.  He got on his knees without being asked.  Jack and Hudson stood behind Microwave, waiting.  Hudson took a sip of his slushie.

“Any last words, man?” Microwave asked, pulling back the slide of his handgun. 

“No.  I’m good,” Edward said, trying to appear casual.  But Edward’s body was visibly shaking.  

“If it makes you feel any better,” Microwave said, levying the gun to the back of Edward’s head, “You seem like a cool guy.  It’s a shame we met under these circumstances.”

“Thanks,” Edward said.  “You seem like a cool guy too.  I would’ve liked to go bowling with you sometime.”  

“Yeah.  Me too.”

Edward felt the cold metal of the gun barrel pressing up against the back of his head.  The quiet strings of the Milk Carton Kids song began to slow.  He looked up at the sky, but he couldn’t see the stars; they were covered by clouds.  Then the song ended.
